ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Over the past 6 weeks, I kept track of the number of drinks I had.
I selected drinks specifically because they were lower in alcohol content.
Over the past 6 weeks, I selected drinks that I tend to drink more slowly.
Over the past 6 weeks, I purposely took small sips of my drink.
Over the past 6 weeks, I set time limits before I allowed myself another drink.
Over the past 6 weeks, I drank nonalcoholic beverages (soft drinks, etc.) between alcoholic drinks.
Over the past 6 weeks, I used body sensations (pleasant feelings, relaxation, slurred speech, etc.) as cues to slow or stop drinking.
Over the past 6 weeks, I refused unwanted drinks.
Over the past 6 weeks, I avoided playing "drinking games".
Over the past 6 weeks, I engaged in activities during drinking that reduce the amount I drink (dancing, etc.).
Over the past 6 weeks, I set a limit on the number of drinks I'd have, before I began drinking.
Over the past 6 weeks, I avoided drinking at places where I tend to overdrink.
Over the past 6 weeks, I set time limits for how long I'd spend drinking.
Over the past 6 weeks, I drank less when I knew I was going to drive.
Over the past 6 weeks, I made arrangements not to drive when drinking.
Over the past 6 weeks, I limited the amount of money I carried, so I would buy less alcohol
Over the past 6 weeks, I limited my access to alcohol by not storing any where I live.
Over the past 6 weeks, I avoided drinking on days and special occasions when I tend to overdrink.
Over the past 6 weeks, I looked for support from my family or friends for my efforts to limit my drinking
Over the past 6 weeks, I confined my drinking to certain times of the week.
Over the past 6 weeks, I drank only after a certain hour of the day.
Over the past 6 weeks, I ate before drinking, to slow the alcohol consumption.
Over the past 6 weeks, I avoided drinking after stressful or emotional experiences.
Over the past 6 weeks, I avoided drinking beer from pitchers, barrels or kegs.
Over the past 6 weeks, I avoided drinking wine or hard liquor directly from the bottle.
Over the past 6 weeks, I avoided drinking during repetitious or boring activities (card playing, etc.)
Over the past 6 weeks, I avoided drinking with heavy drinkers.
Over the past 6 weeks, I avoided drinking with those who pressure me to drink faster or drink more.
Over the past 6 weeks, I looked for information on alcohol and how it affects my body and behavior.
Over the past 6 weeks, I stopped drinking any alcohol for some period of time.
Over the past 6 weeks, I rewarded myself for being able to limit my drinking.
Over the past 6 weeks, I punished or penalized myself for failing to limit my drinking.
Over the past 6 weeks, I thought about the consequences of my drinking to decide if drinking was causing me problems.
Over the past 6 weeks, I substituted other ways of coping with stress, depression, fear or low self-esteem, in place of drinking.
Over the past 6 weeks, I substituted other ways of achieving a "high" or "mellow" feeling, in place of drinking.
Over the past 6 weeks, I substituted other ways of feeling friendly, sociable or able to deal with people, in place of drinking.
Over the past 6 weeks, I substituted other activities (e.g. exercise) in place of drinking.
How effective were the above mentioned strategies in helping you to limit your drinking over the past 6 weeks?
Notes: 1 = Never used; 2 = Not at all effective; 3 = Somewhat effective; 4 = Effective; 5 = Very effective; 6 = Extremely effective

ElementDescription: How effective were these strategies in preventing problems due to drinking over the past 6 weeks?
Notes: 1 = Never used; 2 = Not at all effective; 3 = Somewhat effective; 4 = Effective; 5 = Very effective; 6 = Extremely effective
